subject: Hard Thing About Hard Things – Ben Horowitz
credit: Hard Thing About Hard Things – Ben Horowitz

todos.title: Both peacetime/wartime
todos.body: Some CEOS aren’t equipped to be both peacetime and war-time CEOs.

todos.title: Horowitz Beliefs
todos.body: I believe in artificial deadlines, I believe in playing one against the other, I believe in doing anything and everything short of illegal or immoral to get the damned deal done.

todos.title: Secret of being a CEO
todos.body: Focus and make the best move when there are no good moves.

todos.title: Wartime CEO
todos.body: Fending off imminent existential threats.

todos.title: Management Flaw #1
todos.body: Failure to do performance meetings.

todos.title: Struggle Checklist
todos.body: Don’t put it all on your shoulders, there is always a move to play, don’t take it personally, play long enough and you’re bound to get lucky, this is what separates the women from the girls.

todos.title: Two things technology company must do
todos.body: Build a product that is ten times better than any other product.  Take it to market.

todos.title: Good CEO
todos.body: You must do many things that will upset people in the short run, unnatural things.

todos.title: Technical debt
todos.body: Writing or building shitty products that you have to go back and fix.

todos.title: Nobody cares
todos.body: When things go wrong in your company, nobody cares.  Don’t elaborate your misery, find the impossible solution to get out of your mess.

todos.title: Scaling Management
todos.body: We are doubling employees, therefore you will have a new and very different job and we will want to reevaluate you on the basis of that job.  If it makes you feel better, the rule gores for everyone on the team, including me.

todos.title: CEO focus
todos.body: vision, goals, motivation, decision, follow up.

todos.title: Me vs We
todos.body: The right kind of ambition is in the form of a team and should be heard as we.

todos.title: Functional Training
todos.body: The knowledge and skill people need to do their jobs.

todos.title: Matching Executives
todos.body: The job of a big company CEO is very different than the job of a small company CEO.

todos.title: Single Biggest Personal Improvement as CEO
todos.body: The day I stopped being too positive.  Don’t hold back because you think you will make the problem worse if you transfer it to employees.  Employees can often handle losses much better because they are not as attached to the company.  It will encourage trust, get more brains on the solution, and build culture.

todos.title: Founders
todos.body: Technical founders are the best to run companies.

todos.title: Acquisitions
todos.body: Talent and technology $5 to $50 million, product $25 to $250 million, business $250 and above.

todos.title: Priority
todos.body: Take care of the people, the products, and the profits in that order.

todos.title: Shit sandwich
todos.body: Surrounding negative feedback with positive crap.  Isn’t a great long-term solution.

todos.title: Peter Principle
todos.body: Sooner or later people get promoted to a position where they are not competent.

todos.title: Silver vs. lead bullets
todos.body: Silver bullets are the times you need to pivot.  Lead bullets are when the customer is buying but just not your product.  You have to build a better product.

todos.title: Management debt
todos.body: Short term management decisions with long-term consequences.

todos.title: Calm nerves
todos.body: Share with friends, write it on paper.

todos.title: Management Training
todos.body: Setting expectations for management team.

todos.title: Peacetime CEO
todos.body: Research and development, make things better, expand on the market.

todos.title: Two in the box
todos.body: Putting two people to run one leadership position.  Bad because there is no accountability.

todos.title: Reasons for bad hire
todos.body: Poor job defining the position, hired for lack of weakness instead of strength, hired for scale too soon, hire for a generic position, wrong kind of ambition, failed to integrate the person.

todos.title: Shelf life
todos.body: No technology company has a long shelf life.  Even the best ideas become terrible ideas after time.

todos.title: CEOs
todos.body: Must be good at gathering info and brainstorming and also getting things done.  Can the leader articulate a vision that’s interesting, dynamic, and compelling.

todos.title: User experience
todos.body: Many young companies focus too much on user retention and not enough on user experience.

todos.title: Fundraising
todos.body: Look for a market of one.  You only need one investor to invest, even if you have 30 that say no.

todos.title: Clients and Investors
todos.body: Like people who deliver what they say they are going to deliver.

todos.title: Types of networks
todos.body: large companies to sell to, executives to hire, engineers to hire, press and analysts, investors and acquirers.

todos.title: Good product managers
todos.body: Know the market, competition, CEO of product, well rounded, no excuses, focus, define target, create great collateral for communication, take written positions on important issues, think about value, think about story, err on side of clarity, report weekly.

todos.title: Warrior mentality
todos.body: Keep death in your mind so that you will live each day as it might be your last.

todos.title: Single Man Holdup
todos.body: It always comes down to a single person who can hold the entire project up.  Don’t let people get stuck on things for more than 24 hours.

todos.title: Company is more than one person
todos.body: If you strike out with one person at a company, find out who else you could approach.

todos.title: CA Clause
todos.body: If you release a new version of your software that has functionality of previous version and a new name, then that product is covered under original agreement.

todos.title: Fire with Integrity
todos.body: If you don’t treat the people who leave kindly then the people who stayed would have never trusted us.

todos.title: Don’t Nibble
todos.body: If you are going to eat shit, don’t nibble away at it, swallow it at once and move on.

todos.title: Wartime Speech
todos.body: I need you to do home tonight and have a serious conversation with your wife, husband, significant other, or whoever cares most about you and tell them ‘Ben needs me for the next six months.’ I need you to come in early and stay late.  I will buy you dinner, and I will stay here with you.  Make no mistake, we have one bullet left in the gun and we must hit the target.

todos.title: Wartime General (Mark Cranney)
todos.body: I don’t give a fuck how well trained you are.  If you don’t bring me five hundred thousand dollars a quarter I am going to put a bullet in your head.

todos.title: Hype hyper target
todos.body: Hyper target where your hype should go so you build enough momentum.

todos.title: Colin Powell Moto
todos.body: Hire for strength rather than lack of weakness.

todos.title: Crippling the army
todos.body: Giving your team a task that they cannot possibly perform.

todos.title: Council Review
todos.body: Give promotions via councils.

todos.title: Freaky Friday
todos.body: Get people to switch shoes.

todos.title: Law of Crappy People
todos.body: For any title level, the talent on that level will eventually converge to the crappiest person with that tile.

todos.title: Scaling
todos.body: Find a mentor that’s done it before.  Give ground, specialize, improve communication resources, who makes decisions, process for mitigating issues.

todos.title: Three emotions of startups
todos.body: Euphoria, terror, and hope.

todos.title: Partnerships
todos.body: Either become too tense to tolerate or not tense enough to be productive. Find that middle line.

todos.title: Dump
todos.body: Don’t rely too heavily on one client.

todos.title: Laying off people
todos.body: Don’t let it break the culture, get your head right, don’t delay, it is a company failure, not an individual failure, managers must layoff their own people, address the entire company, be visible afterwards, help the employee move on, use decisive language.

todos.title: Solo decision
todos.body: Despite many people being involved in the process, only the CEO should make the final decision.  Avoids politics.

todos.title: Culture
todos.body: Demand cultural compliance.

todos.title: Andreesen Horowitz model
todos.body: Connect clients to a firm-wide grid of new opportunities.  Firm is more powerful than any one agent.

todos.title: Giving good feedback
todos.body: be authentic, come from the team perspective, don’t get personal, don’t clown in front of peers, not one-sized fits all, be direct but not mean.

todos.title: Size
todos.body: At certain size, your company will do things so bad that you never imagined you would be associated with such incompetence.

todos.title: When Scared
todos.body: Ask yourself what would you do if you went bankrupt.

todos.title: Perks
todos.body: Are not culture (yoga, dogs, etc.)

todos.title: Cultural rules
todos.body: Andreesen Horowitz maker people pay $10 for every minute they are late to a meeting with an entrepreneur to show a sign of respect for that entrepreneur.

todos.title: CEO knowledge
todos.body: A great CEO should get to know and act in every role in the company.
